title: Hearing Aid Prescriptive Methods in an Adult Patient
chief_complaint: I am having difficulty understanding speech, especially in background noise and on the telephone. I feel like my hearing is getting progressively poorer.

problem_summary.onset: Long-term hearing aid user; recent progression noted.
problem_summary.course: Progressive; significant decrease in sensitivity over the last 3 years.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Significant communication deficits in noise and on the phone; current hearing aids feel insufficient.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Self-referred for reprogramming to improve speech understanding.

history.present_illness: Patient self-referred for reprogramming due to perceived decline in hearing.
history.otologic_history: Long-term hearing aid user. No abnormalities on recent MRI or otologic exam.
history.medical_psych_history: Referred to otologist due to asymmetric progression; MRI was normal.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral symmetrical mild to profound sensorineural hearing loss (250-8000 Hz). No measurable hearing at 6-8 kHz. Significant decrease at 2k Hz (Right) and 6-8k Hz (Both) compared to 3 years prior.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs agree with PTAs. Word Recognition Scores (WRS) are very poor at two input levels, suggesting significant retrocochlear or distortion issues (though MRI was normal).

numeric_results.Right_WRS: 30% at 80 dB HL, 28% at 90 dB HL
numeric_results.Left_WRS: 36% at 80 dB HL, 24% at 95 dB HL

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear pressure, volume, and admittance (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Present at 500-2000 Hz at reduced Sensation Levels (SL), suggesting cochlear site of lesion. Absent at 4000 Hz. Decay negative.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: QuickSIN administered. Results suggest maximum improvement in SNR is required (directional mics + HAT).

history.present_illness: Follow-up for hearing aid reprogramming after medical clearance.

tests.name: Electroacoustic Analysis
tests.key_findings: Hearing aids met ANSI S3.22-2009 specifications. No repair needed.

tests.name: Real-Ear Measures (REM)
tests.key_findings: Compared NAL-NL2 vs DSL v5.0 (adult) vs DSL v5.0 (child). Patient found NAL-NL2 'too quiet'. Patient preferred DSL v5.0 child targets due to greater output/loudness.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral symmetrical mild-to-profound sensorineural hearing loss, which has progressed significantly over the last three years. Speech recognition is very poor bilaterally (24-36%), and QuickSIN testing reveals a severe SNR loss of 20 dB. Although the patient is an experienced hearing aid user, standard adult prescriptive targets (NAL-NL2) were perceived as too quiet; the patient achieved better subjective sound quality and loudness with DSL v5.0 child targets.
counseling_points: Due to your poor word recognition scores, a cochlear implant evaluation is strongly recommended.
Hearing aids alone may not be sufficient in noise; a remote microphone or FM system would provide significant benefit.
We have reprogrammed your hearing aids to 'child targets' (DSL v5.0) to provide the extra volume and support you prefer.
Using smartphone apps to stream audio directly to your hearing aids can help with telephone difficulties.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is frustrated that hearing aids aren't helping enough in noise.
When the audiologist tries the first setting (NAL-NL2), complain that it is 'too soft' or 'weak'.
Show immediate preference/relief when the settings are switched to the louder profile (DSL child targets).
